item.title: U.K. royals to get big raise as Crown Estate sees record $1.4 billion profit
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: The Crown Estate’s profits more than doubled in the past year, partly due to lucrative offshore wind farm leases on land owned by the monarchy, meaning a windfall for them and the government.

item.title: Netanyahu dismisses critics, scolds protesters in defiant speech to Congress
item.dc:creator: Abigail Hauslohner, Liz Goodwin, John Hudson
item.description: Evoking Israel’s sworn enemy Iran, Benjamin Netanyahu told Congress his nation’s campaign against Hamas in Gaza is part of a broader fight against “barbarism.”

item.title: North Korean balloon drops trash on South Korean presidential office
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.description: The airborne garbage delivery was the latest, and perhaps most humiliating, episode in the ongoing trash-offensive.

item.title: Anti-Israel protests and threats set tone for politically charged Olympics
item.dc:creator: Rick Noack, Claire Parker
item.description: The Israeli soccer team is set to take the field in Paris on Wednesday, competing in one of the first events of an extremely tense Summer Olympics.

item.title: Netanyahu’s history of clashing with U.S. presidents spans decades
item.dc:creator: Sammy Westfall, Joe Snell
item.description: As Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu returns to Washington this week, here is a look back at some of his most notable clashes with U.S. presidents.

item.title: 1972 Munich Olympics, marred by killing of Israeli athletes, loom over Paris Games
item.dc:creator: Anika Seth
item.description: The 2024 Paris Olympics begin this weekend amid the global fallout over the Oct. 7 attacks on Israel by Hamas and the Gaza war.

item.title: American reality show contestant kills, eats protected bird in New Zealand
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset
item.description: Spencer “Corry” Jones apologized after killing a weka, a large flightless bird with “a famously feisty and curious personality,” on “Race to Survive: New Zealand.”

item.title: Plane slips off runway and crashes at Kathmandu airport, killing 18
item.dc:creator: Sangam Prasai, Maham Javaid
item.description: The Saurya Airlines plane was taking off from Nepal’s Tribhuvan International Airport runway when it flipped, eyewitnesses said. A child is among the dead.

item.title: How ‘carbon cowboys’ are cashing in on protected Amazon forest
item.dc:creator: Terrence McCoy, Júlia Ledur, Marina Dias
item.description: A six-month investigation reveals that many carbon credit ventures reap profits from public lands they have no right to and fail to share revenue with those protecting the forest.

item.title: Taiwan braces for Typhoon Gaemi, set to be the most severe in eight years
item.dc:creator: Vic Chiang, Christian Shepherd
item.description: The powerful storm has already caused deaths and devastation in the Philippines and is now bearing down on Taiwan, where emergency measures are in place.

item.title: Maduro’s decade of authoritarian rule: A visual timeline
item.dc:creator: Samantha Schmidt, Ana Herrero
item.description: How Venezuela’s socialist strongman took and consolidated power — and why the opposition now sees cause for hope.

item.title: Sharks test positive for cocaine in Brazil’s drug-polluted waters
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett
item.description: Brazilian sharpnose sharks found with cocaine in their livers and muscles highlight the impact of the illegal drug trade on marine life, scientists say.

item.title: As Netanyahu addresses Congress, agony in Gaza endures
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: The first time Netanyahu addressed Congress was nearly three decades ago. Now, he arrives in the U.S. amid devastation in Gaza and discontent in Israel.

item.title: China brokers Palestinian unity declaration in bid to be global mediator
item.dc:creator: Christian Shepherd, Steve Hendrix, Niha Masih, Sarah Dadouch
item.description: Though unlikely to paper over the deep differences between Hamas and Fatah, it represents China’s push into a traditionally U.S. area of influence.

item.title: Alleged rape of Australian rattles Paris days before Olympics
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: Officials had said the French capital would be “the safest place in the world” when the Olympic Games began this summer.

item.title: Olympic costs can crush host cities. Paris 2024 vowed cheaper Games.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Francis
item.description: Paris may avert the financial disasters of past Olympics, although its budget is bigger than expected and the benefits remain uncertain.

item.title: Canada’s popular Jasper National Park ordered to evacuate as fire nears
item.dc:creator: Frances Vinall
item.description: An emergency alert warned residents and guests that they must be out by 3 a.m., with instructions to leave via the one remaining open highway.

item.title: India’s indie films win awards abroad but find no space in theaters at home
item.dc:creator: Karishma Mehrotra, Anant Gupta
item.description: The nation’s parallel cinema is racking up Oscars and awards at Cannes but distributors give them little play in India, claiming the audience is too small.

item.title: Why does China care about a rust bucket in the middle of the sea?
item.dc:creator: Michelle Lee, Pei-Lin Wu
item.description: Beijing and Manila have struck a provisional deal to allow the resupply of the dilapidated Sierra Madre in the South China Sea, which has become a potential conflict point.

item.title: Ukraine confronts labor shortage as need for soldiers drains workforce
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Khurshudyan, Serhiy Morgunov
item.description: Ukraine’s urgent need for soldiers to fight Russia’s invasion is eroding the workforce and creating a drag on the economy but also new opportunities for women.

item.title: Israel orders evacuation of former Gaza safe area; U.N. aid convoy fired on
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck, Hajar Harb, Jennifer Hassan
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu traveled to Washington, where the political turmoil was creating further uncertainty about U.S.-Israeli relations.
